abstract_extractions.problem: Osteocytes have been historically regarded as passive but recent data suggest they have multiple functions in bone homeostasis and systemic metabolism.
abstract_extractions.method: Literature review and synthesis of molecular biology and functional studies of osteocytes in bone remodeling and endocrine signaling.
abstract_extractions.finding: Osteocytes are key regulators of bone remodeling through osteoclast and osteoblast control, function as endocrine cells, regulate phosphate and calcium metabolism, and compose 90-95% of adult bone cells.
abstract_extractions.result: Osteocytes are longest-lived bone cells (up to decades); can remodel perilacunar matrix; cell death induced by TNF and glucocorticoids

abstract_extractions.problem: To understand the micromechanical mechanisms underlying mechanical homeostasis in soft tissues at the cellular and fiber scales and how microscale processes lead to macroscopic mechanical homeostasis.
abstract_extractions.method: Bottom-up finite element method computational framework modeling actin cytoskeleton contraction, molecular clutch behavior, and cell interactions with reconstructed three-dimensional extracellular fiber matrix.
abstract_extractions.finding: The framework successfully reproduces experimental observations of mechanical homeostasis on short time scales (hours) and provides a systematic tool for understanding the micromechanical origin of mechanical homeostasis in soft tissues.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Reconstructed three-dimensional extracellular fiber matrix
abstract_extractions.metric: Reproduction of experimental observations on mechanical homeostasis; simulated timescales (hours)
abstract_extractions.result: Successfully reproduced experimental observations of mechanical homeostasis on short time scales

abstract_extractions.problem: Future 5G networks will not meet all requirements beyond 2030, necessitating development of 6G wireless communication networks with enhanced global coverage, spectral/energy efficiency, and security.
abstract_extractions.method: Survey and analysis of enabling technologies including waveform design, multiple access, channel coding, multi-antenna technologies, network slicing, cell-free architecture, and cloud/fog/edge computing for 6G networks.
abstract_extractions.finding: 6G networks will require four paradigm shifts: space-air-ground-sea integrated networks, spectrum expansion (sub-6 GHz to optical), AI/big data for smart applications, and strengthened network security.

abstract_extractions.problem: To develop computational methods for integrative analysis of multiple modalities in single-cell genomics, enabling definition of cellular states based on multiple data types beyond transcriptomics alone.
abstract_extractions.method: Weighted-nearest neighbor (WNN) analysis as an unsupervised framework to learn relative utility of each data type in each cell, applied to CITE-seq dataset with 228 antibodies for multimodal single-cell analysis.
abstract_extractions.finding: WNN analysis substantially improves resolution of cell states, reveals previously unreported lymphoid subpopulations, and enables rapid mapping of new datasets with applications to vaccination and COVID-19 immune responses.
abstract_extractions.dataset: CITE-seq dataset of hundreds of thousands of human white blood cells with 228-antibody panel
abstract_extractions.metric: Cell state resolution; discovery of new subpopulations; mapping accuracy; immune response interpretation
abstract_extractions.baseline: Single-modality transcriptomics approaches
abstract_extractions.result: Substantially improved cell state resolution; identified previously unreported lymphoid subpopulations; validated on vaccination and COVID-19 datasets

abstract_extractions.problem: To quantitatively understand the mechanistic aspects of the angiopoietin-Tie signaling pathway involved in angiogenesis and vascular stability, including the controversial role of Ang2.
abstract_extractions.method: Computational signaling pathway model validated against experimental data, studying receptor activation, trafficking, turnover, and regulatory mechanisms.
abstract_extractions.finding: The model provides mechanistic insights into Ang2 regulation by VE-PTP and Tie1, and predicts synergistic effects of combined inhibition of VE-PTP, Tie1, and Tie2 cleavage on enhancing vascular protective Tie2 signaling.
abstract_extractions.metric: Model validation against experimental data; synergistic effects of pathway inhibition
abstract_extractions.result: Demonstrated synergistic enhancement of Tie2 vascular protective actions through combined pathway inhibition

abstract_extractions.problem: Lacking a unified computational model that predicts cellular growth from molecular scale to whole-cell behavior by integrating metabolic and gene expression pathways.
abstract_extractions.method: Genome-scale ME-Model integrating metabolic and gene product expression pathways with growth optimization principle applied to Escherichia coli.
abstract_extractions.finding: The ME-Model accurately predicts multi-scale phenotypes from growth rate and nutrient uptake to metabolic fluxes and gene expression levels, computing ~80% of functional proteome.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Escherichia coli under various growth conditions
abstract_extractions.metric: Phenotype prediction accuracy across multiple scales
abstract_extractions.baseline: Existing single-process models
abstract_extractions.result: Computes ~80% of functional proteome; unifies existing growth prediction principles

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding fundamental mechanisms generating cell-to-cell regulatory variation from identical DNA sequences and principles of mammalian regulatory variation.
abstract_extractions.method: Single-cell ATAC-seq (scATAC-seq) using programmable microfluidics to map accessible chromatin in individual cells; analysis of regulatory variation patterns.
abstract_extractions.finding: Accessibility variance associates with specific trans-factors and cis-elements; combinations of trans-factors regulate cell-to-cell variability; single-cell patterns link to 3D genome organization.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Single cells from multiple mammalian cell types across eight cell types
abstract_extractions.metric: Chromatin accessibility variance; trans/cis-factor associations
abstract_extractions.result: Maps regulome variation in single cells; recapitulates chromosome compartments de novo

abstract_extractions.problem: Characterizing cell composition and enumerating cell subsets from complex tissue gene expression profiles with noise and unknown mixture content.
abstract_extractions.method: CIBERSORT method using gene expression profiles to characterize hematopoietic cell composition in RNA mixtures from various tissue types.
abstract_extractions.finding: CIBERSORT outperforms other methods in handling noise, unknown mixture content, and distinguishing closely related cell types in tissue samples.
abstract_extractions.dataset: RNA mixtures from fresh, frozen, and fixed tissues including solid tumors
abstract_extractions.metric: Performance on noise, unknown mixture handling, cell type discrimination
abstract_extractions.baseline: Other cell subset enumeration methods
abstract_extractions.result: Outperformed competitors on robustness metrics; enables large-scale analysis for cellular biomarkers

abstract_extractions.problem: Enabling pooled CRISPR screens with comprehensive molecular readouts beyond simple proliferation and marker proteins while maintaining high throughput.
abstract_extractions.method: CROP-seq combines pooled CRISPR screening with single-cell RNA sequencing to link guide RNA expression to transcriptome responses in individual cells.
abstract_extractions.finding: CROP-seq enables high-throughput functional dissection of complex regulatory mechanisms and heterogeneous cell populations with single-cell transcriptome resolution.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Thousands of individual cells from pooled CRISPR screens
abstract_extractions.metric: Single-cell transcriptome resolution; guide RNA coverage
abstract_extractions.baseline: Pooled screens (limited readouts) and arrayed screens (low throughput)
abstract_extractions.result: Achieves pooled screening throughput with single-cell transcriptome readout

abstract_extractions.problem: To design neoantigens for personalized cancer immunotherapy by simulating the complete T-cell epitope presentation process in vivo, improving upon current methods that only predict MHC-peptide binding affinity.
abstract_extractions.method: Integrated in-silico pipeline (Neo-intline) simulating the complete peptide presentation process from SNPs/indels through MHC binding and T-cell recognition, validated on benchmark datasets and in vivo mouse melanoma models.
abstract_extractions.finding: Neo-intline outperforms state-of-the-art tools for neoantigen design and predicts immunogenic peptides that successfully recruit CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, with enhanced therapeutic effects when combined with immune adjuvants or checkpoint inhibitors.
abstract_extractions.dataset: TESLA benchmark dataset; clinically validated neoantigens; mouse melanoma model
abstract_extractions.metric: Prediction accuracy; T-cell recruitment capability (CD4+ and CD8+); therapeutic efficacy in melanoma
abstract_extractions.baseline: Current state-of-the-art neoantigen prediction tools
abstract_extractions.result: Outperformed current tools on sample and melanoma level; 20 validated neoantigens induced T-cell response; enhanced anticancer effects with combination therapies

abstract_extractions.problem: Development of effective killed whole-cell Chlamydia vaccine is hampered by epitope destruction during inactivation process.
abstract_extractions.method: Gamma-irradiated Chlamydia muridarum elementary bodies inactivated in presence of antioxidant Mn2+-decapeptide phosphate (MDP) to protect epitopes while damaging DNA.
abstract_extractions.finding: Gamma-irradiated Cm EBs with MDP protect epitope structure and provide significant protection in murine genital tract infection model with enhanced immune responses.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Chlamydia muridarum elementary bodies; murine genital tract infection model
abstract_extractions.metric: Bacterial burden; clearance rate; IgG and IgA antibody levels; cytokine responses
abstract_extractions.baseline: Unvaccinated controls; EBs irradiated without MDP
abstract_extractions.result: Vaccinated mice exhibited elevated Cm-specific IgG and IgA antibodies, reduced bacterial burdens, and accelerated clearance compared to controls

abstract_extractions.problem: CD44 is a promising cancer stem cell marker in HNSCC but its gene and protein expression patterns and prognostic value need systematic evaluation.
abstract_extractions.method: Computational analysis of CD44 mRNA expression from TCGA HNSCC dataset and protein expression from NCI CPTAC dataset using bioinformatic tools.
abstract_extractions.finding: CD44 mRNA and protein expression levels are significantly higher in HNSCC tissues than normal tissues; high expression correlates with poor survival and is associated with specific clinicopathological characteristics.
abstract_extractions.dataset: TCGA HNSCC dataset (520 primary HNSCC, 44 normal tissues); NCI CPTAC dataset (108 primary HNSCC, 71 normal tissues)
abstract_extractions.metric: mRNA transcript levels; protein expression levels; overall survival; correlation with clinicopathological characteristics
abstract_extractions.baseline: Normal tissues
abstract_extractions.result: CD44 upregulated in Stage 1 and Grade 2 HNSCC; overexpressed in HPV-negative and TP53-positive mutant status

abstract_extractions.problem: To develop an efficient ex vivo model for personalized drug response prediction in breast cancer patients to enable individualized therapy selection.
abstract_extractions.method: Whole-tumor cell culture (WTC) ex vivo model established from breast tumors, with investigation of drug responses across a broad range of therapies and validation against patient clinical responses.
abstract_extractions.finding: WTC model could be established from 98 of 116 breast tumors with stable culture, reassembles parental tumors with endogenous microenvironment, and shows strong clinical associations with patient drug response and treatment outcomes.
abstract_extractions.dataset: 116 breast tumor samples; validation study with 15 neoadjuvant treatment patients
abstract_extractions.metric: Success rate of WTC establishment; accuracy of drug response prediction; correlation with clinical outcomes
abstract_extractions.baseline: Existing patient-derived models
abstract_extractions.result: 98% success rate (98/116); personalized drug testing possible within 10 days; strong correlation with patient clinical responses

abstract_extractions.problem: To determine whether the microtrabecular lattice observed in electron microscopy is an artifact of specimen preparation or represents the true structure of the cytoplasmic ground substance in living cells.
abstract_extractions.method: High voltage transmission electron microscopy of cultured cells with various fixation schedules (chemical and nonchemical), examination of model systems, and comparison with conventionally prepared specimens.
abstract_extractions.finding: The microtrabecular lattice structure consisting of 3-6 nm diameter strands forming a three-dimensional network is preserved across multiple fixation methods and represents the actual nonrandom structure of the cytoplasmic ground substance in living cultured cells.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Cultured cells (WI-38, NRK, chick embryo fibroblasts)
abstract_extractions.metric: Lattice structure preservation across different preparation methods
abstract_extractions.baseline: Model systems and plastic-embedded cells
abstract_extractions.result: Lattice structure confirmed in all cell types examined; not an artifact of critical-point drying

abstract_extractions.problem: Need to identify peptide toxins that block stretch-activated ion channels to understand volume regulation and ion channel mechanisms.
abstract_extractions.method: Venom fractionation using reverse phase HPLC followed by functional assay on stretch-activated channels in outside-out patches from rat astrocytes and isolated ventricular cells.
abstract_extractions.finding: GsMTx-4, a 35 amino acid peptide toxin from spider venom, specifically blocks cation-selective stretch-activated channels with equilibrium dissociation constant of ~630 nM.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Spider venom (Grammostola spatulata), rat astrocytes, rabbit ventricular cells from dilated cardiomyopathy model
abstract_extractions.metric: Equilibrium dissociation constant (Kd), conductance (~45 pS), current reduction percentage
abstract_extractions.baseline: No effect on whole-cell voltage-sensitive currents (negative control)
abstract_extractions.result: ~40% reduction in swelling-activated whole-cell current in astrocytes; near complete block of volume-sensitive cation-selective current in myopathic heart cells; reduced cell size in swell-induced conditions

abstract_extractions.problem: Selecting optimal neoantigen vaccine composition by accounting for tumor heterogeneity and antigen presentation pathway complexity in cancer patients.
abstract_extractions.method: Two-step digital twin approach: simulate individual cancer cells to create patient tumor digital twin, then optimize vaccine composition using integer linear programming.
abstract_extractions.finding: NeoAgDT improved selection of experimentally validated neoantigens compared to ranking-based approaches in seven patient cases.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Seven cancer patients with tumor cells and validated neoantigen data
abstract_extractions.metric: Number of correctly selected experimentally validated neoantigens
abstract_extractions.baseline: Ranking-based vaccine selection approaches
abstract_extractions.result: Improved selection rate over baseline ranking approaches in 7-patient study

abstract_extractions.problem: To create an open-access database and collaborative platform for collecting and sharing crystal structures of small molecules and small to medium-sized unit cells.
abstract_extractions.method: Open-access distribution model with web-based platform enabling registered users to deposit published and unpublished crystal structures through standard open communication protocols.
abstract_extractions.finding: The Crystallography Open Database (COD) successfully aggregated approximately 150,000 crystal structures and established the first world-wide Internet-based collaborative platform for structural knowledge curation and sharing.
abstract_extractions.dataset: COD database with ~150,000 crystal structures
abstract_extractions.metric: Number of aggregated structures; database access capabilities
abstract_extractions.result: ~150,000 structures collected and freely available; support for simultaneous user contributions

abstract_extractions.problem: Systematic gap in knowledge about poorly annotated genes in E. coli that lack experimental evidence of function, affecting whole-cell model building.
abstract_extractions.method: Systematic assembly of gene annotations from EcoCyc, EcoGene, UniProt, and RegulonDB databases to identify genes lacking experimental functional evidence (y-ome).
abstract_extractions.finding: The y-ome comprises 1,600 genes (34.6% of 4,623 unique genes) lacking experimental functional evidence, with y-ome genes enriched for membrane proteins and transporters with lower expression levels.
abstract_extractions.dataset: E. coli K-12 MG1655 genome (4,623 unique genes); annotation databases: EcoCyc, EcoGene, UniProt, RegulonDB
abstract_extractions.metric: Gene annotation status; expression levels; chromosomal location
abstract_extractions.result: 1,600 y-ome genes (34.6%); 111 with absolutely no functional evidence; 220 pseudogenes/phantom genes (4.7%)

abstract_extractions.problem: Inflammatory bowel disease shows heterogeneous clinical and treatment response phenotypes with current therapies showing efficacies of only 40-60%; need to improve therapeutic prediction and personalization.
abstract_extractions.method: Development of multiscale hybrid computational models combining mechanistic approaches with machine learning; creation of digital twins for individual patients to predict treatment responses and IL-6 signaling dynamics.
abstract_extractions.finding: Digital twins focusing on IL-6 biology can enhance credibility of treatment response prediction and enable precision dosing and tailored treatment in IBD.
abstract_extractions.dataset: IBD patient omics data, pathogenesis data, treatment outcome data
abstract_extractions.metric: Treatment efficacy prediction, therapeutic response biomarkers
abstract_extractions.baseline: Current clinical features-based therapeutic planning with 40-60% efficacy rates
abstract_extractions.result: Digital twins and AI-mediated discovery offer potential to improve treatment efficacy beyond current 40-60% rates through precision medicine approaches

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding how mechanical confinement and hypoxia affect tumor cell growth dynamics.
abstract_extractions.method: Dual in vitro-in silico approach combining experimental observations with computational modeling to predict effects of confinement on tumor cell growth.
abstract_extractions.finding: In silico model accurately predicts tumor cell growth dynamics under different mechanical confinement conditions observed in vitro experiments.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Tumor cells cultured in strong and weak confinement conditions
abstract_extractions.metric: Cell growth dynamics; confinement effects

abstract_extractions.problem: Accurate transcript quantification from RNA-Seq data, particularly handling reads mapping to multiple genes/isoforms and lacking reference genomes.
abstract_extractions.method: RSEM software package using statistical modeling to quantify gene and isoform abundances from single-end or paired-end RNA-Seq data without requiring reference genome.
abstract_extractions.finding: RSEM provides accurate transcript quantification comparable to or superior to reference-dependent methods; enables quantification for species without sequenced genomes.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Simulated and real RNA-Seq datasets from various organisms
abstract_extractions.metric: Quantification accuracy for gene and isoform abundances; credibility intervals
abstract_extractions.baseline: Reference-dependent quantification methods
abstract_extractions.result: Superior or comparable performance to reference-based tools; provides 95% credibility intervals

abstract_extractions.problem: Identifying novel CSN kinase inhibitors structurally related to curcumin and emodin to stabilize p53 tumor suppressor and induce cancer cell apoptosis.
abstract_extractions.method: In silico 2D/3D conformer screening against in-house database of 10^6 structures using curcumin and emodin as lead structures; candidates evaluated by Lipinski's rule-of-five and in vitro kinase assays.
abstract_extractions.finding: Seven compounds identified as potent CSN kinase inhibitors (3 curcumin-group including piceatannol, 4 emodin-group including anthrachinone) that increased p53 levels and induced apoptosis.
abstract_extractions.dataset: In-house database with 1,000,000+ chemical structures; 35 initial screening hits; HeLa cancer cells
abstract_extractions.metric: Kinase inhibition activity, p53 protein levels, apoptosis markers (annexin V-FITC, DNA fragmentation, caspase activity)
abstract_extractions.baseline: Parental CSN kinase activity; untreated HeLa cells
abstract_extractions.result: 7 compounds showed potent kinase inhibition and induced apoptosis in tumor cells with increased p53 levels

abstract_extractions.problem: Modeling stochastic cell dynamics in normal human colon crypts to simulate colon cancer initiation and evaluate cancer treatment protocols.
abstract_extractions.method: Agent-based stochastic model in NetLogo simulating cell proliferation and differentiation based on divide and die gradients along crypt axis; parameters calibrated to human biopsy measurements.
abstract_extractions.finding: Virtual crypt model reproduced monoclonal conversion, adenoma formation, cytotoxic recovery, and enabled in silico evaluation of cancer therapy protocols.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Normal human colon crypt biopsy specimens with measured cell type numbers and variations; colon cancer mutation scenarios
abstract_extractions.metric: Number and variation of cell types, quasi-stationary stochastic dynamics verification
abstract_extractions.baseline: Experimental observations of monoclonal conversion, adenoma formation, and therapy response
abstract_extractions.result: Model successfully reproduced all experimentally observed phenomena including neutral drift monoclonal conversion and differential therapy responses

abstract_extractions.problem: Demonstrating the utility of functional digital twin models of cancer cells to investigate ion channel modulation effects on cell cycle progression and develop new cancer therapies.
abstract_extractions.method: Functional in silico A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell digital twin model simulating membrane potential oscillations, ion channel modulation effects, and cell cycle phase transitions.
abstract_extractions.finding: Model simulations demonstrated that TRPC6 blockade causes hyperpolarization suppressing S-G2/M transition and enabling cell cycle arrest; all hypotheses verified experimentally.
abstract_extractions.dataset: A549 lung adenocarcinoma cells; ion channel expression profiles during cell cycle phases; experimental validation studies
abstract_extractions.metric: Membrane potential dynamics, cell cycle phase progression, ion channel functional effects
abstract_extractions.baseline: Wild-type A549 cell behavior; traditional in vivo and in vitro experimental methods
abstract_extractions.result: TRPC6 blockade simulation predicted strong hyperpolarization and S-G2/M arrest; predictions confirmed by experimental validation

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding how computational modeling reveals spatial chromatin conformation properties and genome organization from sequencing technologies in single cells.
abstract_extractions.method: Review of computational techniques for modeling three-dimensional genome structure in single cells versus cell ensembles; assessment of underlying modeling assumptions.
abstract_extractions.finding: Computational modeling techniques reveal spatio-temporal aspects of genome organization from single-cell data with varying assumptions about spatial constraints.

abstract_extractions.problem: Ineffective medication is a major healthcare problem; disease complexity involving altered interactions among thousands of genes across multiple cell types and organs makes individual treatment challenging.
abstract_extractions.method: Development of digital twins as virtual representations of health and disease processes that integrate real-time data and simulations to predict, prevent, and personalize treatments across multiple biological scales.
abstract_extractions.finding: Digital twins have shown potential in areas like artificial organs, cancer, cardiology, and hospital workflow optimization, but widespread implementation requires advances in characterizing dynamic molecular changes, integrating data, and developing interoperable systems.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Multi-scale patient data (genetic, molecular, cellular, tissue, organ levels)
abstract_extractions.metric: Treatment prediction accuracy, clinical outcomes
abstract_extractions.baseline: Current standard-of-care treatment approaches
abstract_extractions.result: Early clinical applications show promise; challenges remain in implementation, integration, and scaling across healthcare systems

abstract_extractions.problem: Dynamically simulating cellular phenotypes arising from integrated signaling, metabolic, and regulatory networks responding to extracellular cues.
abstract_extractions.method: Integrated dynamic FBA (idFBA) framework combining flux balance analysis with stoichiometric reconstruction of signaling, metabolic, and regulatory processes; assumes quasi-steady-state for fast reactions.
abstract_extractions.finding: idFBA enables quantitative dynamic analysis of systemic effects on cellular phenotypes with predictions comparable to kinetic models while avoiding extensive kinetic parameter requirements.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Prototypic integrated system and Saccharomyces cerevisiae modules
abstract_extractions.metric: Time-course phenotype prediction accuracy
abstract_extractions.baseline: Equivalent kinetic models
abstract_extractions.result: Comparable predictions to kinetic models; computationally efficient for genome-scale systems

abstract_extractions.problem: iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes face limitations including phenotypic variability, low-throughput electrophysiological measurements, and immature phenotype that limit translation to adult cardiac response for genetic disease risk stratification.
abstract_extractions.method: Computational iPSC-CM model fitted to experimental ion current data for each KCNQ1 mutation, with population simulations to predict proarrhythmic risk and impact on adult ventricular cardiomyocyte electrophysiology.
abstract_extractions.finding: Computational framework successfully stratified 40 KCNQ1 genetic variants by proarrhythmic risk, with prediction of unknown mutations' severity based on test set of 15 variants with known clinical phenotypes.
abstract_extractions.dataset: 40 KCNQ1 genetic variants (15 with known clinical long QT phenotypes, 25 with unknown clinical significance)
abstract_extractions.metric: Proarrhythmic markers and phenotypic variability in model populations
abstract_extractions.baseline: Known clinical long QT phenotypes from test set of 15 mutations
abstract_extractions.result: Successfully predicted severity of 25 KCNQ1 mutations with unknown clinical significance based on test set validation

abstract_extractions.problem: Large number of parameters in cardiac electromechanics models makes systematic study of links between cellular, tissue, and organ scale parameters to whole heart physiology challenging.
abstract_extractions.method: Patient-specific four-chamber heart electromechanics model using Courtemanche-Land and ToR-ORd-Land cellular models, coupled with CircAdapt circulatory system model. Gaussian processes emulators (GPEs) trained on five hierarchical sub-models for global sensitivity analysis (GSA).
abstract_extractions.finding: GSA identified 45 out of 117 parameters critical for whole heart function; systemic and pulmonary peripheral resistance were identified as most critical parameters affecting volumetric and hemodynamic cardiac indexes across all chambers.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Patient-specific anatomical heart model with 117 parameters across five sub-models
abstract_extractions.metric: Volumetric and hemodynamic cardiac indexes
abstract_extractions.baseline: 90% total sensitivity threshold for parameter retention
abstract_extractions.result: Identified 45 critical parameters; peripheral resistance as key drivers of cardiac function across all four chambers

abstract_extractions.problem: How do cells sense and respond to substrate stiffness through actomyosin contractility? The study investigates the molecular mechanisms underlying cell mechanosensing.
abstract_extractions.method: 3-D Brownian dynamics computational model of a cross-linked actin network including molecular motors and actin cross-linking proteins (ACPs), with evaluation of contraction and stress response to different substrate stiffness.
abstract_extractions.finding: Two mechanisms limit internal stress: in stiff substrates, motors reach maximum force leading to plateau stress; in soft substrates, motors become blocked by other motors/ACPs leading to submaximal stress. This reveals the role of molecular motors in cell rigidity sensing.
abstract_extractions.metric: Contraction and stress measurements in response to substrate stiffness
abstract_extractions.result: Demonstrated independent stress plateau in stiff substrates and stress-dependent response in soft substrates

abstract_extractions.problem: Transcriptome and proteome data show mRNA levels predict only ~40% of protein abundance. Need to understand translation efficiency and translational control mechanisms.
abstract_extractions.method: Bioinformatic analysis of translation efficiency using genome-wide mRNA and protein levels from five human cell lines with protein stability data from HeLa cells.
abstract_extractions.finding: Translation efficiency shows considerable consistency between cell lines for many genes, suggesting translational control and protein degradation regulation are important factors in mRNA-protein correlation.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Five distinct human cell lines with comparable data for 8,170 genes; protein stability data from HeLa cell line
abstract_extractions.metric: Translation efficiency (estimated from mRNA and protein levels combined with protein stability)
abstract_extractions.result: 3,990 genes analyzed in one or more cell lines; 1,807 genes in all five cell lines

abstract_extractions.problem: Making advanced cell biology and structural biology teaching methods accessible to students outside specialized research centers through novel visualization approaches.
abstract_extractions.method: Combining 3D electron microscopy techniques with 3D prototyping technology (3D printing) to generate physical models of cell structures based on EM imaging.
abstract_extractions.finding: Virtual 3D cell models generated from EM data can be 3D printed to create accurate physical models that enhance cell biology education accessibility.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Blood cells and other cellular structures from electron microscopy
abstract_extractions.metric: Educational engagement and accessibility metrics
abstract_extractions.baseline: Traditional teaching methods
abstract_extractions.result: Demonstrates feasibility of creating 3D printed cell models from EM data for educational use

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding whole-neuron electrophysiological dynamics and the role of ion currents in C. elegans neuronal activity and network function.
abstract_extractions.method: Hodgkin-Huxley-based biophysical models of ion channels constructed from C. elegans and homologous channel data; simulations of chemosensory and motor neurons.
abstract_extractions.finding: Models accurately describe regenerative neuronal responses and identify critical roles of T-type calcium and leakage currents in neuronal dynamics including bistability and oscillations.
abstract_extractions.dataset: C. elegans neurons (AWCon chemosensory, RMD motor neuron); ion channel data from multiple organisms
abstract_extractions.metric: Electrophysiological response prediction; ion current contributions
abstract_extractions.result: Successfully predicts wild-type and knockout neuron behavior; identifies bistable and oscillatory regimes

abstract_extractions.problem: To understand plant cell micromechanics and stress-strain-time relationships during dehydration, which is challenging to investigate experimentally due to diminutive spatial and temporal scales.
abstract_extractions.method: Three-dimensional coupled Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) and Coarse-Grained (CG) computational approach to model stress and strain in single plant cells undergoing drying at different levels.
abstract_extractions.finding: The meshfree-based computational model effectively simulates stress and strain behavior in plant cells being compressed during dehydration, ranging from fresh to extremely dried states, with potential applications to other cell types.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Single plant cells at various drying levels and turgor pressures
abstract_extractions.metric: Stress and strain measurements at different dryness levels; strain rates; mechanical properties
abstract_extractions.result: Successfully simulated stress-strain behavior across dryness range from fresh to extremely dried states

abstract_extractions.problem: Treatment selection for sequential versus concurrent chemotherapy and radiation in head and neck cancer lacks evidentiary support and relies on locally optimal decisions at each step.
abstract_extractions.method: Deep Q-learning (DQL) algorithm to train both treatment decision digital twin and patient digital twin, using 536 oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma patients with radiomics analysis of primary tumor volumes.
abstract_extractions.finding: DQL digital twin dyad achieved 87.35% (SD 11.15%) mean and 90.85% (IQR 13.56%) median accuracy in treatment outcome prediction, with predicted survival improvement of +3.73% (95% CI -0.75% to 8.96%).
abstract_extractions.dataset: 536 patients with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma treated at MD Anderson Cancer Center (2005-2013); 402 (75%) for training, 134 (25%) for testing
abstract_extractions.metric: Treatment outcome prediction accuracy, survival rate, dysphagia rate
abstract_extractions.baseline: Clinician treatment decisions and outcomes
abstract_extractions.result: DQL predictions: 87.35% (SD 11.15%) mean accuracy, 90.85% median accuracy; +3.73% (95% CI -0.75% to 8.96%) predicted survival improvement; +0.75% (95% CI -4.48% to 6.72%) dysphagia rate improvement

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding emergent behavior of heterogeneous cell populations in dynamic microenvironments and how metabolism and signaling complexity affect outcomes.
abstract_extractions.method: ARCADE: multi-scale agent-based model for heterogeneous cell agents with variable intracellular metabolism and signaling modules in dynamic microenvironments.
abstract_extractions.finding: Agent-based modeling reveals differences in emergent behavior between colony and tissue contexts, non-linear competition dynamics, and variable impact of cell heterogeneity on outcomes.
abstract_extractions.dataset: In silico case studies on context, competition, and heterogeneity; tumor microenvironments and microbiomes
abstract_extractions.metric: Emergent behavior patterns; parameter variation effects on competition
abstract_extractions.result: Linear, non-linear, and multimodal consequences of parameter variation on competition in co-cultures

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding the role of KNOX family genes in pear cell wall thickening and lignification to improve fruit quality by reducing stone cell content.
abstract_extractions.method: Genome-wide in silico analysis of PbKNOX genes, phylogenetic classification, expression pattern analysis, and functional characterization through Arabidopsis overexpression studies.
abstract_extractions.finding: PbKNOX1 represses lignin biosynthesis genes and reduces secondary cell wall thickness by 19% and lignin content by 13% in transgenic Arabidopsis.
abstract_extractions.dataset: 18 PbKNOX genes identified in pear genome; comparative analysis with grape, mei, and strawberry genomes
abstract_extractions.metric: Secondary cell wall thickness percentage reduction, lignin content percentage reduction
abstract_extractions.baseline: Wild-type Arabidopsis plants
abstract_extractions.result: 19% decrease in secondary cell wall thickness and 13% reduction in lignin content in PbKNOX1 overexpression lines

abstract_extractions.problem: To understand how systemic nutritional status affects immune cell function and metabolism, particularly in T cells, and the mechanisms linking nutrition to immunity.
abstract_extractions.method: Review of studies examining effects of nutritional status (undernutrition, overnutrition) on immune cell populations, circulating cytokines, T cell metabolism, and signaling proteins in human and mouse models.
abstract_extractions.finding: Undernutrition causes immunosuppression increasing infection susceptibility but protecting against autoimmunity, while overnutrition causes chronic inflammation and autoimmunity. Nutritional status regulates T cell metabolism through specific cytokines and hormones acting on signaling proteins.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Human studies and mouse models of nutritional status
abstract_extractions.metric: Circulating cytokine levels; immune cell populations; T cell metabolic state and function
abstract_extractions.result: Identified differential effects of undernutrition (immunosuppression) and overnutrition (chronic inflammation); revealed key regulatory cytokines and hormones

abstract_extractions.problem: Identifying SARS-CoV-2 cell entry inhibitors through drug repurposing to rapidly develop antiviral treatments for COVID-19.
abstract_extractions.method: High-throughput virtual screening of FDA-approved LOPAC library drugs against spike protein receptor binding domain and ACE2 receptor using molecular docking and dynamics simulations.
abstract_extractions.finding: Five compounds identified as ACE2 binders (GR127935, GNF-5, RS504393, TNP, eptifibatide) and five as S-protein binders (KT203, BMS195614, KT185, RS504393, GSK1838705A) with potential anti-inflammatory effects.
abstract_extractions.dataset: FDA-approved LOPAC drug library; SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and ACE2 receptor structures
abstract_extractions.metric: Binding energy, binding modes, molecular dynamics stability
abstract_extractions.baseline: No explicit baseline; comparison across identified molecules
abstract_extractions.result: 10 lead compounds identified with favorable binding modes to viral and host targets

abstract_extractions.problem: Whole-cell model output is complex and high-dimensional, making it difficult to interpret metabolic reaction fluxes and understand cellular responses.
abstract_extractions.method: Analysis pipeline combining machine learning, dimensionality reduction, and network analysis to interpret metabolic reaction fluxes from single gene knockout simulations in Mycoplasma genitalium whole-cell model.
abstract_extractions.finding: Reaction behaviors correlate with phenotypic classes of simulation output; specific reactions can serve as markers of phenotypic classes indicating importance within cellular networks.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Mycoplasma genitalium whole-cell model; single gene knockout simulations
abstract_extractions.metric: Reaction flux patterns; phenotypic class markers; network importance
abstract_extractions.result: Identified reaction sets that can serve as markers of phenotypic classes

abstract_extractions.problem: Understanding bioelectric mechanisms of local calcium dynamics in cancer cell proliferation to develop ion channel-based therapeutic approaches.
abstract_extractions.method: Extended A549 in silico cancer whole-cell ion current model with multicompartmental approach simulating store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) and intracellular calcium dynamics at ER-PM junctions.
abstract_extractions.finding: Local calcium distribution in microdomains significantly impacts electrophysiological properties and regulates cell cycle progression through KCa channel modulation.
abstract_extractions.dataset: A549 non-small cell lung cancer cell line; calcium imaging data from two published experimental studies on CRAC channels and IP3R/RyR function
abstract_extractions.metric: Calcium imaging dynamics, membrane potential modulation, cell cycle phase simulation
abstract_extractions.baseline: Original A549 ion current model without detailed calcium description
abstract_extractions.result: Extended model accurately reproduces calcium imaging dynamics and simulates SOCE mechanisms with improved cell cycle phase predictions

abstract_extractions.problem: LncRNA-mRNA regulation networks play important roles in DLBCL development but the specific regulatory mechanisms are not well understood.
abstract_extractions.method: Batch Cox regression screening for prognosis-related lncRNAs, random forest model for hub lncRNA identification, GO/KEGG pathway enrichment analysis, Spearman correlation analysis, and GSEA.
abstract_extractions.finding: LINC00654-NINL axis identified as a novel regulatory mechanism in DLBCL; high NINL expression associated with therapy response but is a risk factor for overall survival in older patients with advanced-stage cancer.
abstract_extractions.dataset: DLBCL patient datasets; DB and OCILY3 cell lines
abstract_extractions.metric: P-value for therapy response; survival analysis (OS and DSS); expression levels
abstract_extractions.result: p-value = 0.036 for therapy response with high NINL expression; NINL involved in neutrophil-mediated immunity and NF-κB signaling

abstract_extractions.problem: Improving prediction of drug-induced Torsade-de-Pointes (TdP) cardiac arrhythmia risk using in silico cardiac cell models under the CiPA framework.
abstract_extractions.method: Optimization of IKr-dynamic O'Hara Rudy ventricular cell mathematical model with refined parameters from human cardiomyocyte data; novel metric quantifying net electronic charge during action potential.
abstract_extractions.finding: Optimized model with new metric successfully classified drug-induced TdP risk across wide concentration and pacing rate ranges and showed correlation with EAD robustness.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Published human cardiomyocyte experimental data under drug block and control conditions; manual patch clamp data
abstract_extractions.metric: Net electronic charge during action potential, early afterdepolarization (EAD) induction robustness
abstract_extractions.baseline: Original O'Hara Rudy ventricular cell model; historical CiPA validation compounds
abstract_extractions.result: Metric successfully classifies TdP risk at both clinical and high drug concentrations; improved correlation with EAD phenomena

abstract_extractions.problem: Current animal models for predicting drug-induced cardiotoxicity have limited accuracy and raise ethical concerns. Need fast and accurate alternatives for early drug safety prediction.
abstract_extractions.method: In silico drug trials using population of human ventricular action potential models (n=1,213) tested against 62 reference compounds at multiple concentrations using pore-block drug models.
abstract_extractions.finding: In silico drug trials with human AP models predict clinical risk of pro-arrhythmic cardiotoxicity with higher accuracy than animal models, with drug-induced changes in biomarkers agreeing across different assays.
abstract_extractions.dataset: 1,213 human ventricular AP models; 62 reference compounds; validation with rabbit wedge preparations and hiPS-CM recordings
abstract_extractions.metric: Accuracy in predicting clinical Torsade de Pointes arrhythmias; AP duration changes; QT interval; QRS complex
abstract_extractions.baseline: Rabbit wedge preparations; hiPS-CM Ca2+-transient recordings
abstract_extractions.result: 89% accuracy in predicting clinical risk for all compounds; AP duration changes reflect rabbit QT interval and hiPS-CM Ca2+-transient changes

abstract_extractions.problem: Validating in silico human cardiac Purkinje cell models for drug-induced proarrhythmia risk prediction to support regulatory approval of pharmaceutical drugs.
abstract_extractions.method: In silico simulations of 14 reference compounds on human cardiac Purkinje cell population models; comparison with in vitro rabbit data and clinical proarrhythmia outcomes.
abstract_extractions.finding: In silico human Purkinje models predicted arrhythmia risk with higher accuracy than rabbit in vitro experiments, with high consistency between human simulations and rabbit recordings.
abstract_extractions.dataset: 14 reference compounds; in vitro rabbit electrophysiology data; clinical proarrhythmia reports; human Purkinje cell population models
abstract_extractions.metric: Five electrophysiological biomarkers at three pacing frequencies; depolarization velocity; action potential duration
abstract_extractions.baseline: In vitro rabbit cardiac electrophysiology; historical clinical proarrhythmia classifications
abstract_extractions.result: In silico predictions showed higher accuracy than rabbit models; consistent biomarkers with rabbit data except species-specific differences in dofetilide, sotalol, terfenadine

abstract_extractions.problem: Finding new molecules for chemotherapeutic treatment of cancer through evaluation of natural alkaloid fractions from Amaryllidaceae species.
abstract_extractions.method: In vitro cell line testing against six cancer cell lines combined with molecular docking studies of alkaloids against anti-cancer molecular targets (Bcl-2 family proteins, HK2).
abstract_extractions.finding: Powelline and buphanidrine alkaloids from Crinum jagus and Eucharis bonplandii showed strong cytotoxic activity against gastric cancer cells with reduced cell viability.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Six cancer cell lines (AGS, BT-549, HEC-1B, MCF-7, MDA-MB 231, PC3) with HaCat control; 30 Amaryllidaceae alkaloids identified
abstract_extractions.metric: Cell viability percentage
abstract_extractions.baseline: HaCat control cell line; wild-type untreated cancer cells
abstract_extractions.result: Crinum jagus 48.06% ± 3.35% and Eucharis bonplandii 45.79% ± 3.05% cell viability at 30 µg/mL in AGS cells

abstract_extractions.problem: Developing and evaluating whole-cell bioreporters for monitoring bioremediation and environmental contamination in various matrices.
abstract_extractions.method: Pseudomonas fluorescens HK44 strain engineered with bioluminescent luxCDABE phenotype linked to naphthalene degradation; application in soil, water, and air matrices.
abstract_extractions.finding: HK44 functions as a well-characterized chemically-responsive environmental bioreporter enabling monitoring of bioremediation processes and bacterial colonization dynamics.
abstract_extractions.dataset: HK44 strain performance across soils, sands, water, wastewater, and volatile environments
abstract_extractions.metric: Bioluminescent emission kinetics; bioremediation monitoring capability
abstract_extractions.result: First genetically engineered microorganism released in field for bioremediation monitoring

abstract_extractions.problem: Industrial systems require realistic and fully functional process simulations; need to develop digital twins incorporating Industry 4.0 enabling technologies.
abstract_extractions.method: Development approach for digital twins in industrial environments incorporating automation, robotics, cloud computing, system integration, and augmented reality. Implementation using Unity for 3D modeling, Vuforia SDK for AR, Node-RED for system integration, and MQTT for communications.
abstract_extractions.finding: Digital twins enhanced with Industry 4.0 technologies (system integration, industrial protocols, cloud services, automation) provide significant added value for industrial process simulation and robotic system modeling.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Industrial robotic electro-pneumatic cell simulation data
abstract_extractions.metric: Process simulation accuracy and functionality
abstract_extractions.baseline: Traditional industrial process modeling without digital twin technology
abstract_extractions.result: Successfully demonstrated digital twin development of robotic electro-pneumatic cell using proposed multi-technology integration approach

abstract_extractions.problem: Lepidoptera insects display very high radioresistance compared to mammals and other insect orders; understand the role of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) in this resistance mechanism.
abstract_extractions.method: In silico structural and functional analysis of Lepidopteran NOS compared to mammalian nNOS, including sequence homology, tertiary structure prediction, post-translational phosphorylation prediction, and intracellular localization analysis.
abstract_extractions.finding: Lepidopteran NOS has higher phosphorylation score (0.885±0.02 vs 0.694±0.094 in mammals) and primarily cytoplasmic localization, which may reduce NOS activation by radiation stress and limit oxidative damage amplification.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Lepidopteran NOS and mammalian nNOS sequences and structures
abstract_extractions.metric: Phosphorylation score (Net Phos 2.0), intracellular localization score (WoLFPSORT)
abstract_extractions.baseline: Mammalian nNOS phosphorylation and localization patterns
abstract_extractions.result: Lepidopteran NOS phosphorylation score 0.885±0.02 vs mammalian 0.694±0.094; localization score 23 vs 10 in mammals; primarily cytosolic localization predicted to contribute to radioresistance

abstract_extractions.problem: Determine whether spatial navigation and neuronal firing patterns in virtual reality environments match those observed in real open arenas in head-restrained mice.
abstract_extractions.method: Virtual reality system with head movement restriction to horizontal rotations, compatible with multi-photon imaging, comparing place cell, grid cell, and head-direction cell firing patterns between VR and real arena conditions.
abstract_extractions.finding: Place and grid cells showed broader spatial tuning in VR; place cells more directional in VR; theta frequency increased less with running speed in VR, while theta phase precession and firing rate changes were similar between conditions.
abstract_extractions.dataset: Head-restrained mice during virtual navigation of open arenas and real open arenas
abstract_extractions.metric: Spatial tuning, directional firing, theta frequency, firing rates, theta phase precession
abstract_extractions.baseline: Real arena firing patterns as reference
abstract_extractions.result: Omni-directional place cell firing in real arenas requires local cues unavailable in VR; scale of firing patterns and theta frequency reflect motion cues from both visual/proprioceptive (VR) and vestibular/extra-maze (real) sources

fulltext_extractions.problem: Characterize the molecular biology and physiological functions of osteocytes, which comprise 90-95% of bone cells but were previously considered passive.
fulltext_extractions.method: Literature review synthesizing recent molecular, transgenic, and imaging studies; discussion of osteocyte signaling mechanisms and mechanotransduction pathways.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Osteocytes function as orchestrators of bone remodeling through regulation of osteoclasts and osteoblasts, act as endocrine cells, and sense mechanical load through dendritic processes, cilia, and hemichannels to release signaling molecules.
fulltext_extractions.result: Osteocyte health essential for bone functionality; mechanical loading triggers rapid release of nitric oxide, ATP, and prostaglandin; deletion of mechanosensing machinery (e.g., PC-1, P2X7) reduces bone anabolic response by 70%

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding the micromechanical mechanisms of mechanical homeostasis in soft tissues, particularly how cell-ECM interactions at the microscale lead to macroscopic tissue-level mechanical homeostasis.
fulltext_extractions.method: Finite element method (FEM) computational framework modeling 3D fiber networks, actin cytoskeleton contraction, and molecular clutch behavior of individual cells interacting with reconstructed extracellular matrix.
fulltext_extractions.finding: The framework reproduces experimental observations of mechanical homeostasis on short time scales (hours) and demonstrates how cell density and collagen concentration relate to homeostatic stress through mechanobiological mechanisms.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Reconstructed 3D collagen type I fiber networks with realistic geometric characteristics (valency, free-fiber length, orientation correlation)
fulltext_extractions.metric: Homeostatic tension maintenance, cell-mediated remodeling (RMT), stress-strain relationships
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Previous decellularized ECM models limited to 2D systems with one or two cells; current models lack long-term remodeling (deposition/degradation)
fulltext_extractions.result: Reproduces experimental observations of mechanical homeostasis on short time scales; validated against constrained gel tension experiments showing two-phase response (phase I rapid increase to homeostatic tension, phase II maintenance)

fulltext_extractions.problem: Fifth generation (5G) wireless networks will not meet future requirements beyond 2030. Future 6G networks need to provide global coverage, enhanced spectral/energy/cost efficiency, better intelligence and security.
fulltext_extractions.method: Survey of enabling technologies including waveform design, multiple access, channel coding, multi-antenna technologies, network slicing, cell-free architecture, and cloud/fog/edge computing. Integration of AI and big data technologies.
fulltext_extractions.finding: 6G will enable four paradigm shifts: (1) space-air-ground-sea integrated networks combining terrestrial, satellite and UAV communications; (2) exploration of all spectrum bands from sub-6 GHz to terahertz and optical; (3) smart applications enabled by AI and big data; (4) strengthened network security.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Resolving functionally distinct but molecularly similar immune cell states that cannot be separated by single-modality transcriptomics alone, particularly T cell subsets (effector, regulatory, γδ, MAIT).
fulltext_extractions.method: Weighted-nearest neighbor (WNN) analysis framework learning cell-specific modality weights to integrate multiple data types (RNA + protein) and define cellular states based on relative utility of each modality.
fulltext_extractions.finding: WNN analysis substantially improves resolution of immune cell states and identifies previously unreported lymphoid subpopulations in CITE-seq dataset of hundreds of thousands of human white blood cells.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: CITE-seq dataset of ~500,000 human white blood cells with 228-antibody panel; multimodal reference atlas of circulating immune system
fulltext_extractions.metric: Cell type resolution, discovery of novel subpopulations, mapping accuracy to reference atlas, immune response interpretation (vaccination, COVID-19)
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Standard scRNA-seq alone; sequential analysis (first RNA clustering, then immunophenotyping) cannot separate similar T cell subsets
fulltext_extractions.result: Demonstrated superior resolution of T cell subsets and immune populations; successful mapping of vaccination and COVID-19 immune responses to multimodal reference

fulltext_extractions.problem: Mechanistic aspects of angiopoietin-Tie signaling pathway remain incompletely understood, particularly the controversial role of Ang2 and its regulators VE-PTP and Tie1 in vascular stability and angiogenesis.
fulltext_extractions.method: Computational signaling pathway model of angiopoietin-Tie system validated against experimental data. Model includes receptor activation, trafficking, turnover, and molecular mechanisms of pathway regulation.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Model predicts synergistic effects of inhibiting VE-PTP, Tie1, and Tie2 cleavage on enhancing vascular protective actions of Tie2. Provides mechanistic insights into Ang2's context-dependent roles and controversial regulatory mechanisms.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Computational model validated against experimental data; parameters derived from literature and experimental studies
fulltext_extractions.metric: Receptor activation levels, downstream signaling output, synergy metrics for dual/triple inhibition
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Existing experimental observations of Ang1/Ang2 agonistic and antagonistic properties
fulltext_extractions.result: Model shows synergistic enhancement of Tie2 signaling with simultaneous inhibition of VE-PTP, Tie1, and Tie2 cleavage; reconciles controversial experimental findings on Ang2 and Tie1 roles

fulltext_extractions.problem: Predicting cellular growth phenotypes requires a unified computational model that integrates metabolic and gene expression pathways across molecular and cellular scales.
fulltext_extractions.method: Constructed an ME-Model (Metabolic-Expression Model) for E. coli that seamlessly integrates metabolic reactions and gene expression pathways using genome-scale optimization principles.
fulltext_extractions.finding: The ME-Model successfully predicts multi-scale phenotypes from growth rate and nutrient uptake to metabolic fluxes and gene expression levels, computing ~80% of the functional proteome.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Escherichia coli K-12 MG1655 genome-scale networks
fulltext_extractions.metric: Growth rate prediction, metabolic flux prediction, gene expression level prediction
fulltext_extractions.baseline: M-Models (metabolism-only models), Whole-cell model of Mycoplasma genitalium
fulltext_extractions.result: ~80% proteome coverage; accurate prediction of growth rate (μ*), substrate uptake, metabolic fluxes, and gene expression levels

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding cellular regulatory variation requires mapping chromatin accessibility at single-cell resolution to reveal how gene regulatory elements vary across individual cells.
fulltext_extractions.method: Developed scATAC-seq using Tn5 transposase on microfluidic platforms to tag accessible chromatin in individual cells with >500-fold sensitivity improvement; mapped 254 individual lymphoblastoid cells.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Single-cell accessibility profiles reveal cell-to-cell variation in trans-factors and cis-elements; accessibility variance is associated with specific regulatory factors and three-dimensional genome compartments.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 254 individual GM12878 lymphoblastoid cells; additional cell lines (H1 ESCs, K562, mouse ESCs, etc.)
fulltext_extractions.metric: Fragments per cell, accessibility variance, correlation with chromosome compartments
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Bulk ATAC-seq, DNase-seq
fulltext_extractions.result: Average 7.3×10^4 fragments per cell; aggregate scATAC-seq profiles match bulk ATAC/DNase measurements; >500-fold sensitivity improvement

fulltext_extractions.problem: Characterizing cellular composition in complex tissues from gene expression profiles requires robust deconvolution methods tolerant of noise, unknown mixture content, and closely related cell types.
fulltext_extractions.method: CIBERSORT employs linear support vector regression (SVR) with adaptive feature selection to deconvolve cell-type mixtures from bulk gene expression profiles using reference signature matrices.
fulltext_extractions.finding: CIBERSORT outperformed six competing methods on idealized and real mixtures, achieving high accuracy on poorly defined and noisy samples including solid tumors.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: LM22 leukocyte signature matrix (547 genes, 22 hematopoietic phenotypes); external tumor and tissue samples
fulltext_extractions.metric: Sensitivity, specificity, AUC, deconvolution accuracy
fulltext_extractions.baseline: LLSR, QP, PERT, RLR, MMAD, DSA methods
fulltext_extractions.result: 93% accuracy on purified leukocyte subsets; ≥94% sensitivity and ≥95% specificity (AUC ≥0.98) at P<0.01

fulltext_extractions.problem: Pooled CRISPR screens are limited to simple readouts like cell proliferation; arrayed screens support transcriptome profiling but have low throughput due to physical separation requirements.
fulltext_extractions.method: CROP-seq combines pooled CRISPR screening with single-cell RNA sequencing using droplet-based scRNA-seq to detect both guide RNA and transcriptome in individual cells, enabling pooled screens with single-cell resolution.
fulltext_extractions.finding: CROP-seq enables pooled CRISPR screens with single-cell transcriptome readout, facilitating high-throughput functional dissection of complex regulatory mechanisms and heterogeneous cell populations.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Single cells from pooled CRISPR-transduced populations
fulltext_extractions.metric: gRNA assignment success rate, genome editing efficiency, indel signatures, detected genes per cell
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Traditional pooled CRISPR screens (simple readouts) and arrayed CRISPR screens (low throughput)
fulltext_extractions.result: Most cells successfully assigned to one gRNA; gRNA assignment rate associated with transcriptome quality (number of detected genes)

fulltext_extractions.problem: Bridging the gap between high in-silico prediction accuracy (80-90%) and low clinical effectiveness in neoantigen vaccine design by modeling the complete T-cell immune presentation process.
fulltext_extractions.method: Integrated computational pipeline (Neo-intline) simulating complete antigen presentation from SNPs/indels through proteasome hydrolysis, TAP transport, MHC-peptide binding, and TCR recognition for both MHC-I and MHC-II pathways.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Neo-intline outperforms state-of-the-art tools on both sample and melanoma level; top 10 MHC-I and top 10 MHC-II peptides successfully recruited CD4+ and CD8+ T cells in mouse melanoma models with significant anticancer effects when combined with checkpoint inhibitors.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: TESLA benchmark dataset, clinically validated neoantigens, melanoma patient samples, mouse B16F10 melanoma model
fulltext_extractions.metric: T-cell priming efficiency, tumor growth inhibition, CD4+/CD8+ T cell recruitment, TIL infiltration, MDSC reduction
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Standard in-silico pipelines (NeoVax, Neo-MoDC) focusing only on MHC-peptide binding affinity; current methods ignore proteasome hydrolysis and TCR recognition steps
fulltext_extractions.result: Validation of 20 neoantigens (10 MHC-I + 10 MHC-II) in mouse melanoma; significant tumor suppression with combination therapy (vaccine + anti-PD-1/PD-L1 or poly(I:C))

fulltext_extractions.problem: Develop an effective killed whole-cell vaccine for Chlamydia trachomatis by overcoming epitope destruction during inactivation, a longstanding challenge in vaccine development.
fulltext_extractions.method: Prototype vaccine using elementary bodies (EBs) from Chlamydia muridarum inactivated by gamma irradiation with Mn2+-Decapeptide (MDP) antioxidant protection. Murine genital tract infection model used for protection assessment. Serum antibody, neutralization assay, and splenocyte cytokine analysis performed.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Gamma-irradiated Cm EBs with MDP (Ir-Cm+MDP) confer significant protection with preserved epitope structure. Vaccinated mice show elevated Cm-specific IgG/IgA, reduced bacterial burdens, accelerated clearance, and distinctive Th1/Th17 cytokine responses compared to unvaccinated controls and EBs irradiated without MDP.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Female BALB/c mice (n=4-5 per group) vaccinated with Ir-Cm+MDP, with challenge by C. muridarum intravaginally at day 10. Splenocytes harvested at day 38.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Bacterial CFU burden, antibody titers (ELISA, LOD 1:1000), serum neutralization titer, cytokine panel (17-plex), clearance rate.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Unvaccinated controls and mice vaccinated with EBs irradiated without MDP protection.
fulltext_extractions.result: Significant protection in murine genital tract model. Elevated IgG/IgA antibodies, reduced bacterial burdens, accelerated clearance. Distinctive cytokine profile supporting Th1/Th17 responses vs controls.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Evaluate CD44 gene and protein expression in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) and assess its clinical utility as a diagnostic/prognostic biomarker and therapeutic target for cancer stem cell (CSC) markers.
fulltext_extractions.method: In silico computational analysis using Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) HNSCC dataset accessed through UALCAN portal for mRNA expression and CPTAC dataset for protein expression. Association with clinicopathological features (age, gender, grade, stage, HPV status, p53 mutation) and survival analyzed.
fulltext_extractions.finding: CD44 mRNA and protein expression significantly elevated in HNSCC vs normal tissues. High CD44 expression correlates with poor survival. Upregulation observed in Stage 1, Grade 2 HNSCC, HPV-negative, and TP53-positive mutant cases. CD44 can serve as diagnostic/prognostic biomarker.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: TCGA HNSCC: 520 primary tumors + 44 normal tissues. CPTAC: 108 primary HNSCC + 71 normal tissues.
fulltext_extractions.metric: mRNA transcript levels, protein expression levels, survival correlation analysis, clinicopathological feature associations.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Normal tissue CD44 expression levels; comparison across different tumor grades and stages.
fulltext_extractions.result: CD44 mRNA/protein significantly higher in HNSCC than normal. High CD44 correlated with poor survival. Overexpression in Stage 1, Grade 2, HPV-negative, TP53-positive mutant cases.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Patient-to-patient variability in drug response complicates breast cancer treatment prediction. Existing patient-derived models have limitations that impede clinical application for individualized therapy.
fulltext_extractions.method: Whole-tumor cell culture (WTC) ex vivo model established from breast tumors via tumor scraping cells (TSCs). Non-selective culturing for 4-5 days enables drug profiling against broad range of BC therapies.
fulltext_extractions.finding: WTC model can be stably established from 98/116 breast tumors (98% success rate) with endogenous microenvironment reassembly. WTC-based test results strongly correlate with patients' clinical responses in validation study (15 BC patients with neoadjuvant treatment).
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 116 breast tumor samples, 15 patient validation cohort with neoadjuvant treatment regimens
fulltext_extractions.metric: Establishment success rate (98%), predictive accuracy for drug response, correlation with clinical outcomes
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Cell lines, patient-derived xenografts (PDX), organoid cultures
fulltext_extractions.result: 98% success rate (98/116 tumors); personalized drug testing completed within 10 days; predictive values supported by clinical correlation in 15-patient validation cohort

fulltext_extractions.problem: Whether the microtrabecular lattice observed in electron micrographs is an artifact of specimen preparation or represents actual cytoplasmic ground substance structure remains uncertain.
fulltext_extractions.method: High voltage transmission electron microscopy (HVEM) of cultured cells (WI-38, NRK, chick embryo fibroblasts) subjected to various chemical fixation (glutaraldehyde/osmium) and nonchemical (freezing) protocols, with critical-point drying.
fulltext_extractions.finding: The microtrabecular lattice structure is preserved across different fixation methods and appears in all portions of the cytoplasm. The structure closely represents the nonrandom structure of the cytoplasmic ground substance in living cells, not an artifact.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Whole cultured cells (WI-38, NRK, chick embryo fibroblasts) and model systems (erythrocytes, protein solutions)
fulltext_extractions.metric: Preservation of lattice structure across fixation methods, electron micrograph comparison
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Conventional plastic-embedded sectioned cell preparations
fulltext_extractions.result: Critical-point drying and freeze-drying methods reliable; lattice preserved under chemical and nonchemical fixation; discrepancies with plastic-embedded samples attributed to embedding resin electron-scattering properties

fulltext_extractions.problem: Stretch-activated channels (SACs) lack a specific peptide inhibitor. Existing blockers like Gd3+ are non-specific and affect multiple channel types. Need specific tool to study SACs in volume regulation and mechanotransduction.
fulltext_extractions.method: Isolated 35 amino acid peptide toxin (GsMTx-4) from spider venom using reverse-phase HPLC fractionation and patch-clamp electrophysiology assay on outside-out patches from astrocytes.
fulltext_extractions.finding: GsMTx-4 blocks cation-selective SACs with high specificity (Kd ~630 nM). Produces ~40% reduction in swelling-activated whole-cell current in astrocytes and near-complete block in dilated cardiomyopathy cells. Reduces cell size in myopathic hearts by blocking tonically active swell-induced current.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Adult rat astrocytes; isolated rabbit ventricular cells from dilated cardiomyopathy model
fulltext_extractions.metric: Equilibrium dissociation constant (Kd); conductance (~45 pS); current reduction percentage
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Gadolinium (Gd3+) as non-specific SAC blocker
fulltext_extractions.result: Kd ~630 nM; 40% current reduction in astrocytes; near-complete block in cardiomyopathy cells

fulltext_extractions.problem: Selecting optimal neoantigens for personalized cancer vaccines is complex due to tumor heterogeneity and the need to consider antigen presentation pathways. Current ranking-based approaches risk excluding promising targets.
fulltext_extractions.method: Two-step approach: (1) Digital twin simulation of patient tumor cell population modeling antigen presentation pathway steps (peptide processing, MHC binding, gene expression) using pVACtools; (2) Integer linear programming optimization to maximize immune response likelihood in simulated population while respecting vaccine manufacturing budget constraints.
fulltext_extractions.finding: NeoAgDT shows improved selection of experimentally validated neoantigens compared to ranking-based approaches in seven patient studies. Digital twin approach enables optimization accounting for tumor heterogeneity.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Seven cancer patient samples; RNA sequencing data from Tran et al. (2015) (accession PRJNA342632); tumor-specific mutations and HLA typing data
fulltext_extractions.metric: Neoantigen selection accuracy; immune response likelihood; coverage of heterogeneous cancer cell populations
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Ranking-based neoantigen selection approaches; traditional threshold-based filtering methods
fulltext_extractions.result: Improved selection performance over ranking-based approaches in 7 patient cases; approach demonstrated on melanoma and other tumor types with quantitative comparison to conventional methods

fulltext_extractions.problem: Crystal structure data are traditionally locked behind subscription-based databases, limiting scientific collaboration and knowledge growth. Need for open-access crystallographic database.
fulltext_extractions.method: Crystallography Open Database (COD) developed as internet-based collaborative platform for collection and curation of small molecule/small to medium sized unit cell crystal structures. Enables registered users to deposit published and unpublished structures.
fulltext_extractions.finding: COD has successfully aggregated approximately 150,000 crystal structures with growth rate of ~40,000 entries/year. Platform provides open-access distribution, multiple search capabilities, and download options via standard protocols.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 150,000 crystal structures (organic, inorganic, metal-organic compounds, minerals); structures from single crystal diffraction, powder diffraction, or theoretical calculations
fulltext_extractions.metric: Total structures collected (150,000), growth rate (40,000 entries/year), technical capacity for doubled growth
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Subscription-based traditional databases (Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, others)
fulltext_extractions.result: 150,000 structures collected and freely available; growth rate ~40,000/year; technical capacity exists to double growth rate through collaborative platform model

fulltext_extractions.problem: Systematically identify and characterize unannotated genes ('y-ome') in E. coli K-12 MG1655 lacking experimental evidence of function; assess annotation gaps in model organism.
fulltext_extractions.method: Systematic assembly and cross-validation of gene annotations from multiple knowledge bases (EcoCyc, EcoGene, UniProt, RegulonDB); statistical and comparative analysis of gene properties.
fulltext_extractions.finding: 1,600 of 4,623 E. coli genes (34.6%) lack experimental evidence of function; y-ome genes tend to have lower expression, enriched in chromosome termination region, and primarily annotated as membrane proteins and transporters.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: E. coli K-12 MG1655 genome annotations from EcoCyc, EcoGene, UniProt, RegulonDB; 111 genes with absolutely no functional evidence
fulltext_extractions.metric: Percentage of unannotated genes; gene expression levels; chromosomal distribution; protein class distribution
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Prior estimates: 2009 study identified 1,431 unannotated genes; 2015 EcoliNet identified ~2,000 genes
fulltext_extractions.result: 34.6% of genes (1,600) lack experimental evidence; 111 have zero evidence; 220 genes (4.7%) are pseudogenes/phantom genes; y-ome genes show lower expression and specific chromosomal enrichment

fulltext_extractions.problem: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is heterogeneous with current therapies showing only 40-60% clinical efficacy, and therapeutic plans are determined by clinical features without specific biomarkers, limiting precision medicine approaches.
fulltext_extractions.method: Review of multiscale hybrid computational models combining mechanistic approaches and machine learning to predict IBD therapy response, with focus on IL-6 pathway modeling and digital twin generation for patient-specific predictions.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Multiscale models integrating IL-6 signaling pathways with machine learning can predict therapeutic responses and enable precision dosing. Virtual digital twins offer improved prediction accuracy for personalized medicine in IBD.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Clinical trial data, omics data, and IBD patient cohorts from published multiscale models
fulltext_extractions.metric: Treatment response prediction, biomarker prediction, model accuracy
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Current clinical treatment selection based on clinical features alone (40-60% efficacy)
fulltext_extractions.result: Multiscale models demonstrate potential for improved therapy selection; digital twins enhance prediction credibility but specific quantitative improvements not uniformly reported across studies

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understand how mechanical stress and hypoxia interact to control tumor cell growth in constrained environments. Unclear whether necrotic cores form due to mechanical pressure or restricted oxygen diffusion.
fulltext_extractions.method: Dual in vitro-in silico approach combining multicellular tumor spheroids in alginate capsules with biophysical mathematical model using fluid analogy and finite element method simulation.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Mathematical model successfully predicts tumor growth and necrotic core formation observed in vitro, demonstrating coupling between mechanical stress and oxygen availability as key regulators of tumor expansion.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Multicellular tumor spheroids (MCTS) in spherical and cylindrical alginate gel capsules with measured strain data
fulltext_extractions.metric: Model prediction accuracy validated against experimental spheroid growth kinetics and capsule strain measurements
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Previous homeostatic pressure model (Helmlinger et al.); prior pressure-only models without oxygen coupling
fulltext_extractions.result: Model reproduces measured pressure (5-15 kPa threshold) and predicts growth inhibition; successfully validates on cylindrical configuration after parameter identification on spherical case

fulltext_extractions.problem: Quantifying transcript abundances from RNA-Seq data is complicated by multimapping reads and unclear isoform assignments, especially without reference genomes.
fulltext_extractions.method: RSEM implements expectation-maximization statistical modeling with likelihood-based inference to handle read mapping uncertainty and estimate gene/isoform abundances with credibility intervals.
fulltext_extractions.finding: RSEM achieves superior or comparable accuracy to reference-dependent methods and demonstrates that short single-end reads provide better gene-level quantification than paired-end reads for fixed sequencing depth.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Simulated and real RNA-Seq datasets; MAQC samples
fulltext_extractions.metric: Quantification accuracy vs. qRT-PCR; gene-level and isoform-level abundance estimates
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Simple read counting, LLSR, other isoform-level methods
fulltext_extractions.result: Comparable or superior accuracy to reference-dependent methods; short SE reads optimal for gene-level accuracy

fulltext_extractions.problem: Identifying new CSN kinase inhibitors more effective than curcumin and emodin for tumor cell apoptosis induction.
fulltext_extractions.method: In silico 2D/3D conformer screening using 3D similarity search algorithm to compare lead structures (curcumin and emodin) against in-house database of >1,000,000 compounds, followed by Lipinski's rule-of-five filtering and in vitro kinase assays.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Identified 7 novel compounds (3 curcumin-group including piceatannol, 4 emodin-group including anthrachinone) as potent CSN kinase inhibitors that increased p53 levels and induced apoptosis in tumor cells.
