fulltext_extractions.dataset: In-house chemical database with >1,000,000 structures; HeLa tumor cells for in vitro validation.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Annexin V-FITC binding, DNA fragmentation, caspase activity assays to assess apoptosis; kinase inhibition assays.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Lead structures curcumin and emodin previously shown to inhibit CK2, PKD and CSN complex.
fulltext_extractions.result: Novel compounds demonstrated enhanced CSN kinase inhibition and induced apoptosis as measured by multiple biomarkers in cell culture.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding cell dynamics in normal human colon crypts and simulating the initiation and treatment of colon cancer through computational modeling.
fulltext_extractions.method: Agent-based stochastic model developed in NetLogo simulating cell proliferation and differentiation based on position-dependent gradients along the crypt axis.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Successfully developed a calibrated virtual crypt model that reproduces measured variation in cell types and demonstrated its utility by evaluating different cancer chemotherapy and radiation scheduling protocols.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Multiple human colon biopsy specimens with measurements of stem cells, proliferating cells, and differentiated cells.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Model verification based on ability to reproduce monoclonal conversion, adenoma formation, and crypt recovery from cytotoxic perturbation.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Previous mathematical models based on mouse tissue and deterministic approaches that did not account for cell type variation.
fulltext_extractions.result: Model produced quasi-stationary stochastic dynamics matching experimentally observed monoclonal conversion and adenoma formation patterns.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Developing functional in silico cell models to understand ion channel modulation of cell cycle progression and cancer cell electrophysiology.
fulltext_extractions.method: First functional (non-phenomenological) digital twin of A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell electrophysiology incorporating Hodgkin-Huxley type ion channel models and hidden Markov models; simulated membrane potential oscillations during cell cycle phases and ion channel modulation effects.
fulltext_extractions.finding: A549 digital twin successfully predicted cell cycle progression modulation through ion channel activation/inactivation; blockade of TRPC6 channels resulted in hyperpolarization suppressing S-G2/M transition enabling cell cycle arrest; simulated hypotheses verified by experimental studies.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Patch clamp and fluorescence imaging experimental data from A549 cancer cells; ion channel expression data across cell cycle phases.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Membrane potential changes; cell cycle phase transitions; ion channel conductance modulation; cell proliferation, mitosis, and apoptosis rates.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Previous phenomenological agent-based models lacking detailed mathematical descriptions of biological mechanisms; traditional in vivo and in vitro tumor models.
fulltext_extractions.result: Digital twin accurately predicted promotion or interruption of cell cycle progression through targeted ion channel modulation; all simulated hypotheses verified by experimental validation.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Computational modeling of 3D genome structure from single-cell Hi-C data is challenging due to sparsity, heterogeneity, and need to distinguish significant interactions from random contacts.
fulltext_extractions.method: Computational techniques for modeling three-dimensional genome conformation in single cells versus cell ensembles using Hi-C sequencing data, contact frequency matrices, and distance constraints.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Single-cell Hi-C structures provide more information on structural variance than deconvoluted structures from ensemble cells; consensus methods poorly address structural heterogeneity while deconvolution techniques enable inference of substructures.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Genome-wide Hi-C sequencing from single cells and cell populations
fulltext_extractions.metric: Contact frequencies between chromosome regions, 3D distance matrices, structural variance metrics
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Population-averaged Hi-C methods producing single consensus chromatin structure
fulltext_extractions.result: Data sparsity in single-cell Hi-C does not prevent structure modeling; hundreds of single-cell structures needed to determine structural variance

fulltext_extractions.problem: Ineffective medication is a major healthcare problem; many patients with complex diseases do not respond to treatment or experience serious side effects, requiring personalized and predictive approaches to medicine.
fulltext_extractions.method: Digital twin technology that creates virtual representations of health and disease processes integrating real-time data and simulations across multiple biological scales to predict, prevent, and personalize treatments.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Digital twins have emerged as promising approach for predictive, preventive, and personalized medicine, with early clinical applications showing potential in artificial organs, cancer, cardiology, and hospital workflow optimization.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Multi-omics analyses, patient data across whole-body systems and organs
fulltext_extractions.metric: Treatment efficacy, side effects, disease progression prediction
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Current medication approaches with variable treatment response (ineffective in many patients)
fulltext_extractions.result: Early clinical applications demonstrate potential; widespread implementation faces challenges in data integration, interoperability, and ethical considerations

fulltext_extractions.problem: Integrated analysis of signaling, metabolic, and regulatory networks requires quantitative dynamic simulation considering that these processes operate at multiple time scales and are highly interconnected.
fulltext_extractions.method: Integrated dynamic flux balance analysis (idFBA) that combines flux balance analysis with quasi-steady-state assumptions for fast reactions and time-delayed incorporation of slow reactions into stoichiometric formalism.
fulltext_extractions.finding: idFBA enables quantitative, dynamic analysis of systemic effects of extracellular cues on cellular phenotypes without requiring exhaustive kinetic parameters, generating comparable time-course predictions to equivalent kinetic models.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Prototypic integrated system with signaling-metabolic-regulatory features and Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast module
fulltext_extractions.metric: Time-course dynamic profiles of intracellular species
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Kinetic models (require extensive kinetic parameters) and pure steady-state FBA (cannot generate dynamic profiles)
fulltext_extractions.result: idFBA solves linear programming efficiently and scales to genome-scale integrated systems without exhaustive kinetic parameter lists

fulltext_extractions.problem: iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes suffer from phenotypic variability despite identical genotypes, low-throughput electrophysiological measurements, and immature phenotype. Need high-throughput method to predict proarrhythmic risk of KCNQ1 genetic variants linked to long QT syndrome.
fulltext_extractions.method: Computational modeling of iPSC-CMs with population-based approach. IKs model fitted to experimental data for each KCNQ1 mutation. Simulated impact in population of iPSC-CM models to predict proarrhythmic risk.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Tremendous phenotypic variability observed in iPSC-CM model population following mutant perturbations. Method predicted severity of KCNQ1 mutations with unknown clinical significance. Results mapped to adult ventricular cardiomyocyte electrophysiology to predict mutation impact across aging continuum.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 40 KCNQ1 genetic variants tested; 15 with known clinical long QT phenotypes for training; 25 with unknown clinical significance
fulltext_extractions.metric: Proarrhythmic markers; phenotypic variability measures; action potential duration
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Clinical long QT phenotypes (test set)
fulltext_extractions.result: Successfully stratified proarrhythmic risk of KCNQ1 mutations using population-based computational framework

fulltext_extractions.problem: Four-chamber cardiac electromechanics models have 117 parameters, making systematic study of links between cellular, tissue, and organ-scale parameters to whole heart physiology challenging. Need efficient methods for parameter importance identification for patient-specific digital twins.
fulltext_extractions.method: Patient-specific anatomical heart model with Courtemanche-Land (atria) and ToR-ORd-Land (ventricles) ionic models coupled to CircAdapt circulatory system. Trained Gaussian processes emulators (GPEs) on five hierarchical sub-models for global sensitivity analysis (GSA).
fulltext_extractions.finding: Identified 45 out of 117 parameters explaining 90% of total sensitivity. Systemic and pulmonary peripheral resistance are critical parameters for volumetric and hemodynamic cardiac indexes across all four chambers. GPEs enable robust mapping between cellular properties and clinical measurements.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Four-chamber cardiac model with 117 parameters across tissue electrophysiology, ionic dynamics, passive mechanics, and circulatory coupling
fulltext_extractions.metric: Sensitivity indices; global sensitivity analysis; parameter importance ranking
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Full 117-parameter model
fulltext_extractions.result: Reduced to 45 critical parameters (38.5% of original); identified systemic/pulmonary resistance as key drivers; enables patient-specific model calibration

fulltext_extractions.problem: How cells sense matrix stiffness via actomyosin contractility remains unclear. The study investigates the mechanical mechanisms underlying cellular rigidity sensing in response to substrate elasticity.
fulltext_extractions.method: 3-D Brownian dynamics computational model of a cross-linked actin network including molecular motor dynamics and actin cross-linking proteins (ACPs). Network contraction and stress evaluated under different substrate stiffness conditions.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Two mechanisms limit internal stress: (i) stiff substrates - motors exert maximum force leading to plateau stress independent of substrate stiffness; (ii) soft substrates - motors become blocked by other motors or ACPs, leading to submaximal stress.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Computational actin network model with parameterized motor and ACP dynamics
fulltext_extractions.metric: Network contraction stress, plateau stress, motor stalling fraction
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Spring models (two-spring and three-spring models) from literature
fulltext_extractions.result: Model reproduces mechano-sensing responses with stress showing substrate-dependent behavior: plateau stress in stiff substrates, lower stress in soft substrates due to motor blocking

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understand the discrepancy between mRNA and protein levels in human cells, where mRNA predicts only ~40% of protein abundance. The study aims to estimate translation efficiency (TE) to build improved models for interpreting mRNA expression data.
fulltext_extractions.method: Bioinformatic analysis combining genome-wide mRNA and protein levels from five human cell lines with protein stability data from pulsed SILAC experiments to estimate translation efficiency (TE = protein abundance / (mRNA level × protein stability)).
fulltext_extractions.finding: Translation efficiency shows considerable consistency across cell lines for many genes (3,990 genes in one or more cell lines, 1,807 in all five). Deviations from consistency likely result from protein degradation regulation and known translational control mechanisms.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Five human cell lines (MCF-7, HeLa, A-431, U-2 OS, U-251 MG) with paired mRNA (high throughput sequencing) and protein (mass spectrometry) levels covering 8,170 genes total.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Coefficient of variation (CV) of translation efficiency calculated on gene-by-gene basis across cell lines; Gene Ontology and KEGG pathway enrichment analysis with Benjamini-corrected p-values.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Comparison against expected simple model where mRNA increases would have concomitant protein increases.
fulltext_extractions.result: 3,990 genes analyzed for translation efficiency in one or more cell lines; 1,807 genes analyzed across all five cell lines. Online resource created for exploring TE in genes of interest.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Cell biology education lacks engaging teaching methods for modern cell structure concepts, especially electron microscopy techniques that are inaccessible to most students in developing countries.
fulltext_extractions.method: Three-dimensional electron microscopy techniques (serial sectioning TEM, serial electron tomography, vectorization) combined with 3D printing to generate realistic physical models of cells for educational purposes.
fulltext_extractions.finding: 3D printed cell models derived from EM data successfully engage students and modernize cell biology teaching; vectorized models enable visually impaired students to understand intracellular structures through tactile exploration.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Blood cell ultrastructures imaged by TEM: neutrophil, monocyte
fulltext_extractions.metric: Student engagement assessment, teaching effectiveness, model realism compared to actual ultrastructure
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Traditional 2D textbook illustrations, movies, and animations
fulltext_extractions.result: Virtual models can be deposited on platform and downloaded for printing in schools, increasing accessibility of modern cell biology teaching approaches

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding C. elegans neuronal electrical activity requires comprehensive single-cell biophysical models accounting for multiple ion channel types and their voltage/calcium dependencies.
fulltext_extractions.method: Constructed Hodgkin-Huxley-based mathematical models of 14 ion channel types using experimental electrophysiological data and genetic expression information; simulated whole-cell dynamics of AWCon and RMD neurons.
fulltext_extractions.finding: The models accurately describe regenerative responses and identify heterogeneous RMD dynamics including bistable regimes and sustained oscillations; T-type calcium currents (CCA-1) and leakage currents are critical.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: C. elegans connectome and ion channel literature; experimental data from multiple organisms
fulltext_extractions.metric: I-V curve predictions, voltage responses to current stimuli, activation/inactivation kinetics
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Simplified ion current models, single-process models (calcium-only)
fulltext_extractions.result: Accurate prediction of whole-cell I-V curves and regenerative responses; identified critical role of CCA-1 channels in RMD bistability

fulltext_extractions.problem: Investigating micromechanical behavior of plant cells during drying and dehydration, accounting for stress-strain-time relationships across different dryness levels and external loading conditions.
fulltext_extractions.method: 3D coupled Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) and Coarse-Grained (CG) meshfree computational approach modeling cell wall, cell fluid, and turgor pressure dynamics under compression.
fulltext_extractions.finding: The meshfree-based model effectively simulates stress and strain behavior in plant cells from fresh state to extremely dried state under different levels of compression, turgor pressures, and strain rates.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Single plant cell model with varying turgor pressures, cell sizes, mechanical properties, and strain rates during drying conditions
fulltext_extractions.metric: Stress-strain-time relationships, turgor pressure effects, deformation behavior
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Previous DEM models by Loodts et al. (2006) and van Liedekerke et al. (2013); current methods limited to small periodic tissues without 3D realistic heterogeneity
fulltext_extractions.result: Successfully simulates micromechanical behavior across dryness spectrum; demonstrates capability to extend to other cell types and biological structures with model modifications

fulltext_extractions.problem: Selection of patients for sequential versus concurrent chemotherapy and radiation regimens lacks evidentiary support and is based on locally optimal decisions, failing to systematically incorporate both oncologic and toxicity endpoints.
fulltext_extractions.method: Deep Q-learning (DQL) with digital twin dyad approach applied to head and neck cancer treatment data; patient digital twin predicts outcomes while treatment decision digital twin determines optimal multi-step treatment strategies with respect to survival and toxicity metrics.
fulltext_extractions.finding: DQL digital twin dyad achieved 87.35% mean and 90.85% median accuracy in treatment outcome prediction, improving predicted survival rate by 3.73% and dysphagia rate by 0.75% compared to clinician decisions on test set.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 536 patients with oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma from MD Anderson Cancer Center (2005-2013), with 402 for training (75%) and 134 for testing (25%); radiomics analysis of primary tumor volumes
fulltext_extractions.metric: Treatment outcome prediction accuracy, survival rate, dysphagia rate
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Clinician treatment decisions based on clinical features and heuristics
fulltext_extractions.result: Test set: mean 87.35% (SD 11.15%) accuracy, median 90.85% (IQR 13.56%) accuracy; predicted survival improvement +3.73% (95% CI -0.75% to 8.96%), dysphagia improvement +0.75% (95% CI -4.48% to 6.72%)

fulltext_extractions.problem: Predict emergent behavior of heterogeneous cell populations in dynamic microenvironments; understand how intracellular complexity impacts population-level dynamics.
fulltext_extractions.method: Multi-scale agent-based model (ARCADE) with heterogeneous cell agents following rules-based behavior in simulated environments; explores context, competition, and heterogeneity effects.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Complexity of intracellular metabolism and signaling modules drives emergent behavior; cell density-dependent competition and phenotypic heterogeneity produce non-linear and multimodal responses to parameter variation.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: In silico simulations of heterogeneous cell populations in colony and tissue contexts
fulltext_extractions.metric: Emergent population dynamics and cell growth patterns
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Equation-based models; homogeneous cell models without environmental context
fulltext_extractions.result: Significant differences in emergent behavior between colony and tissue contexts; cell heterogeneity produces variable impact on outcomes; competition shows linear, non-linear, and multimodal parameter dependencies

fulltext_extractions.problem: Stone cells reduce pear fruit quality by causing rough texture and poor flavor. Secondary cell wall thickening and lignification are key drivers of stone cell development. KNOX transcription factors regulate lignin biosynthesis but are uncharacterized in pear.
fulltext_extractions.method: Genome-wide identification of 18 PbKNOX genes; phylogenetic analysis and chromosomal localization; spatiotemporal expression profiling using qRT-PCR; functional characterization by overexpressing PbKNOX1 in Arabidopsis; measurement of secondary cell wall thickness and lignin content via microscopy and chemical analysis.
fulltext_extractions.finding: PbKNOX1 (BP orthologue) represses lignin biosynthesis, reducing secondary cell wall thickness and lignin accumulation. PbKNOX1 transcript levels inversely correlate with stone cell and lignin accumulation. Gene represses key lignin biosynthesis structural genes.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 18 PbKNOX genes from Pyrus bretschneideri; comparative analysis with 9 KNOX genes in grape, 11 in mei, 11 in strawberry; transgenic Arabidopsis overexpressing PbKNOX1
fulltext_extractions.metric: Secondary cell wall thickness (measured in transgenic vs wild-type); lignin content percentage (%); gene expression fold-change (qRT-PCR); phylogenetic conservation scores
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Wild-type Arabidopsis plants; Arabidopsis BP (AtBP) orthologue comparison; untransformed control plants
fulltext_extractions.result: PbKNOX1 overexpression: 19% decrease in secondary cell wall thickness of vessel cells; 13% reduction in lignin content of inflorescence stems; significant (P < 0.01) difference from wild-type; downregulation of multiple lignin biosynthesis genes (PAL, CAD, CCR, COMT, CCoAOMT)

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding how systemic nutritional status (undernutrition vs. overnutrition) affects T cell metabolism and immune function, and identifying metabolic targets for immunity-related disorders.
fulltext_extractions.method: Review of literature on nutritional status effects on immune cell metabolism, focusing on cytokines and hormones mediating nutrition-immune interactions (TNF-α, IL-6, leptin, adiponectin, AMPK signaling).
fulltext_extractions.finding: Undernutrition suppresses immunity increasing infection susceptibility; overnutrition causes chronic low-grade inflammation increasing metabolic disease and autoreactivity; T cell metabolism is sensitive to both nutrient deficiency and excess.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Mouse models, human studies examining metabolic status, immune cell populations, and T cell function under varied nutritional conditions
fulltext_extractions.metric: Cytokine levels (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-17, IFN-γ), immune cell populations, T cell differentiation (Th1, Th17), metabolic enzyme activity (PFKFB3, BCAT1)
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Traditional immunology models ignoring systemic metabolic effects; single-nutrient or single-modality analyses
fulltext_extractions.result: Identified key metabolic targets (PFKFB3, BCAT1) for modulating T cell function; demonstrated hormonal and cytokine mediation of nutrition-immune interactions; established therapeutic opportunities for malnutrition and obesity-related immunology

fulltext_extractions.problem: SARS-CoV-2 pandemic requires rapid identification of entry inhibitors. The spike protein (S-protein) binding to ACE2 receptor is a promising therapeutic target for drug repurposing.
fulltext_extractions.method: High-throughput virtual screening of FDA-approved LOPAC drug library against two targets: spike protein receptor-binding domain (S-RBD) and ACE2 receptor. Molecular docking, binding energy analysis, and molecular dynamics simulations. Screening based on S-protein binding motifs and ACE2 receptor interaction sites.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Five compounds identified binding to ACE2 virus-binding motifs (GR127935, GNF-5, RS504393, TNP, eptifibatide); five compounds identified binding to S-protein RBD (KT203, BMS195614, KT185, RS504393, GSK1838705A). These molecules may inhibit virus entry and possess anti-inflammatory properties.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: FDA-approved LOPAC library of drugs; SARS-CoV-2 spike protein receptor-binding domain structure; ACE2 human receptor structure; ~1,800,000 infected individuals as context (as of April 2020)
fulltext_extractions.metric: Binding energy; binding modes; molecular interaction strength; hotspot residue binding (Lys31, Lys353 on ACE2; key S-RBD residues)
fulltext_extractions.baseline: No antiviral drugs available at screening time; compared to known antivirals (remdesivir, lopinavir, ritonavir, chloroquine) mentioned as context
fulltext_extractions.result: 10 candidate molecules identified with favorable binding predictions; S-RBD affinity to ACE2 approximately 10-fold higher than historical SARS-CoV (2003); affinity indicates strong binding potential; results require in vivo validation

fulltext_extractions.problem: Interpret complex, high-dimensional metabolic flux output from whole-cell models without detailed knowledge of constituent parts; identify biomarkers of phenotypic classes.
fulltext_extractions.method: Analysis pipeline combining machine learning, dimensionality reduction (t-SNE), network analysis, and neural networks on single gene knockout simulations in Mycoplasma genitalium whole-cell model.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Reaction flux behaviors correlate with phenotypic classes; specific metabolic reactions serve as markers for phenotypic classes; analysis pipeline enables interpretation of whole-cell model complexity.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Mycoplasma genitalium whole-cell model flux data from single gene knockouts; 28 submodels representing cellular processes
fulltext_extractions.metric: Neural network classification accuracy for flux behavior phenotypes; network centrality of marker reactions
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Manual eye-based analysis; existing visualization tools with limited processing capability
fulltext_extractions.result: Machine learning successfully classifies reaction behaviors into phenotypic classes; fewer than 10 reactions consistently affected in DNA/septum disruptions; significantly more reactions affected in protein/RNA disruptions

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding bioelectric properties and calcium dynamics in cancer cells is critical for developing ion channel-targeted therapeutics. Store-operated calcium entry (SOCE) significantly affects cancer cell electrophysiology and cell cycle progression.
fulltext_extractions.method: Extension of A549 computational whole-cell ion current model with multicompartmental calcium dynamics description. Detailed mathematical modeling of ER-PM junction calcium microdomains, store-operated calcium entry (SOCE), SERCA pump uptake, RyR and IP3 receptor release. Model parameters fitted to experimental calcium imaging data from two published studies. Simulations of calcium dynamics across cell cycle phases (G1, S, G2/M).
fulltext_extractions.finding: Extended A549-SOCE model accurately reproduces calcium imaging dynamics and SOCE mechanisms. Local calcium distribution in microdomains significantly impacts overall electrophysiological properties and cell cycle progression. Ca2+ dynamics regulate downstream KCa channels and membrane potential.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: A549 non-small cell lung cancer cell line; experimental calcium imaging data from two published studies; cell cycle phase-specific measurements; ion channel expression data
fulltext_extractions.metric: Cytosolic calcium concentration [Ca2+]Cyt (nM); extracellular [Ca2+]Ext (mM); ER calcium [Ca2+]ER (µM); calcium imaging dynamic fit accuracy; membrane potential (mV); model validation against experimental data
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Original A549 ion current model (without detailed SOCE); experimental calcium imaging measurements; established calcium homeostasis parameters ([Ca2+]Cyt ~100 nM, [Ca2+]Ext >1 mM, [Ca2+]ER >100 µM)
fulltext_extractions.result: Model successfully reproduces calcium imaging dynamics; demonstrates SOCE upregulation at G1/S transition and downregulation S to G2/M; simulates functional roles of CRAC channels, SERCA, PMCA, RyR, and IP3R in calcium homeostasis; accurately models local calcium entry of store-operated calcium channels

fulltext_extractions.problem: Identify novel lncRNA-mRNA regulatory networks in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) to understand disease progression mechanisms and discover potential therapeutic targets, as current treatments fail in ~33% of patients.
fulltext_extractions.method: Bioinformatics pipeline: Batch Cox regression for prognosis-related lncRNAs, random forest for hub lncRNA identification, Spearman correlation for target gene prediction, GO and KEGG enrichment analysis, Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) for functional mechanisms.
fulltext_extractions.finding: LINC00654 identified as hub lncRNA with 1,443 candidate target genes enriched in GTPase and Notch signaling pathways. LINC00654-NINL axis validated; high NINL expression associated with better therapy response (p=0.036) but is a risk factor for overall and disease-specific survival in older/advanced-stage patients. NINL may involve neutrophil immunity and NF-κB signaling.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 47 DLBCL patients from TCGA database and GSE32018/GSE18376 datasets with complete clinical follow-up data (age, sex, histology, stage).
fulltext_extractions.metric: Cox regression p-values, Spearman correlation coefficients, GO/KEGG p-values with Benjamini correction, survival analysis (p=0.036 for therapy response).
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Other lncRNA-mRNA regulatory networks previously identified in various cancers.
fulltext_extractions.result: LINC00654-NINL regulatory axis newly identified in DLBCL. High NINL expression is a risk factor for OS/DSS in older (p<0.05) and advanced-stage patients. NINL high in DB cell line, low in OCILY3.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Improving prediction of drug-induced Torsade-de-Pointes (TdP) arrhythmia risk across a wide range of drug concentrations and pacing rates.
fulltext_extractions.method: Optimized O'Hara Rudy ventricular cell mathematical model incorporating Markov model of IKr for dynamic drug-channel interactions; refined parameters using human cardiomyocyte experimental data; developed novel metric quantifying net electronic charge from ionic currents during action potential.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Optimized IKr-dynamic ORd model successfully classified drug-induced TdP risk across wide concentration and pacing rate ranges; metric correlated with cell robustness against early afterdepolarization (EAD) induction.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Published human cardiomyocyte experimental data under control and drug block conditions; patch clamp recordings; 28 CiPA reference drugs (12 for calibration, 16 for validation).
fulltext_extractions.metric: Electronic charge metric; early afterdepolarization (EAD) robustness; action potential duration; drug concentration and pacing frequency effects.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Original O'Hara Rudy model; previous computational frameworks using IC50-based drug effects without dynamic drug-channel interactions.
fulltext_extractions.result: Optimized model improved consistency with experimental data and enabled accurate TdP risk classification at concentrations near and above clinical exposure.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Develop human-based computational models for early prediction of drug-induced cardiotoxicity that outperform animal models and provide faster, cheaper alternatives to experimental assays.
fulltext_extractions.method: In silico drug trials using a population of 1,213 human ventricular action potential (AP) models based on O'Hara-Rudy dynamic (ORd) model. Drug effects modeled using pore-block models (IC50/Hill coefficient) on ion channels. AP biomarkers quantified and compared against rabbit wedge ECG and hiPS-CM Ca2+ transient recordings.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Repolarization abnormalities in silico predict clinical risk of pro-arrhythmic cardiotoxicity with 89% accuracy. Drug-induced AP changes correlate across assays: in silico AP duration changes reflect rabbit QT interval and hiPS-CM Ca2+ transient changes. Models with low repolarization reserve are most vulnerable to drug-induced abnormalities.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 62 reference compounds at multiple concentrations tested on 1,213 human ventricular AP models. Validation subset of 15 compounds compared against rabbit wedge ECG and hiPS-CM recordings.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Prediction accuracy (89%), repolarization reserve assessment, AP biomarker changes (AP duration, upstroke velocity, occurrence of abnormalities).
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Animal models (rabbit wedge, isolated heart, in vivo dog models) with reported 75% accuracy for TdP prediction.
fulltext_extractions.result: 89% accuracy for predicting clinical pro-arrhythmic risk using in silico drug trials. Drug-induced changes show overall agreement across in silico, rabbit QT, and hiPS-CM assays.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Validating in silico human cardiac Purkinje cell models for proarrhythmic risk prediction and comparing their accuracy to in vitro animal models.
fulltext_extractions.method: Population-based in silico human cardiac Purkinje models simulating electrophysiological effects of 14 reference drugs at multiple pacing frequencies; comparison with in vitro rabbit Purkinje fiber experiments and clinical proarrhythmia reports; quantified five electrophysiological biomarkers per drug dose.
fulltext_extractions.finding: In silico human Purkinje models predicted drug-induced arrhythmia with higher accuracy than rabbit experiments; showed high consistency with in vitro recordings; depolarization velocity and action potential duration were most consistent biomarkers; discrepancies for dofetilide, sotalol and terfenadine due to species differences.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Population of in silico human cardiac Purkinje models; 14 reference compounds with known clinical proarrhythmia risk; in vitro rabbit Purkinje preparations; clinical proarrhythmia reports.
fulltext_extractions.metric: Action potential duration, depolarization velocity, repolarization abnormalities, EAD induction; drug dose response at three pacing frequencies.
fulltext_extractions.baseline: In vitro rabbit Purkinje fiber preparations; current ICH S7B/E14 guideline approaches based on hERG assay and QTc interval.
fulltext_extractions.result: Human in silico models demonstrated superior accuracy for proarrhythmia prediction compared to animal models while maintaining consistency with experimental data.

fulltext_extractions.problem: Cancer is a major cause of death and requires new chemotherapeutic compounds. Finding new alkaloid-based molecules for cancer treatment with reduced toxicity.
fulltext_extractions.method: In vitro cytotoxicity screening of alkaloid fractions from Amaryllidaceae species against six cancer cell lines, combined with molecular docking studies to predict binding to anti-cancer protein targets (Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, Mcl-1, HK2). In vitro plant tissue culture propagation and statistical analysis (ANOVA, PCA, PLS-DA).
fulltext_extractions.finding: Crinum jagus and Eucharis bonplandii showed best cytotoxic activity against gastric cancer AGS cells. Powelline and buphanidrine alkaloids demonstrated potential anti-cancer activity through combined in vitro and in silico analysis.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Six cancer cell lines: AGS, BT-549, HEC-1B, MCF-7, MDA-MB-231, PC3; HaCat control cells; 30 Amaryllidaceae alkaloids tested
fulltext_extractions.metric: Cell viability percentage (%); molecular docking binding affinity; hydrogen bonding and π-π stacking interactions
fulltext_extractions.baseline: HaCat control cell line; wild-type plant materials compared to tissue-cultured propagation
fulltext_extractions.result: Crinum jagus: 48.06 ± 3.35% cell viability at 30 µg/mL; Eucharis bonplandii: 45.79 ± 3.05% at 30 µg/mL (lower is better for cytotoxic activity); p ≤ 0.05 considered significant

fulltext_extractions.problem: Monitoring bioremediation potential and detecting environmental pollution using whole-cell bioreporters that respond to chemical contaminants.
fulltext_extractions.method: Pseudomonas fluorescens HK44 bioreporter strain expressing bioluminescent luxCDABE phenotype linked to naphthalene degradative pathway for chemically-responsive environmental monitoring.
fulltext_extractions.finding: HK44 functions as one of the best characterized chemically-responsive environmental bioreporters and model organism for understanding bacterial colonization, transport, cell immobilization, and bioluminescent emission kinetics.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Multiple environmental matrices: soils, sands, water, wastewater, and volatile environments
fulltext_extractions.metric: Bioluminescent signal intensity and emission kinetics
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Other bioreporter systems using GFP, luc luciferases, and non-specific stress-responsive reporters
fulltext_extractions.result: First genetically engineered microorganism released in field for bioremediation monitoring since 1990

fulltext_extractions.problem: Industrial digitization requires integration of multiple enabling technologies (Industry 4.0) including automation, robotics, cloud computing, and digital twins to optimize production processes and enhance efficiency.
fulltext_extractions.method: Development of digital twins using Unity as 3D engine with Vuforia SDK for augmented reality, Node-RED for system integration, MQTT protocol for communications, and cloud-based services for data storage and processing in robotic electro-pneumatic cells.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Digital twins developed through integrated Industry 4.0 technologies enable real-time simulation, predictive maintenance, and enhanced monitoring, improving operational efficiency in industrial systems while reducing costs compared to proprietary automation tools.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Robotic electro-pneumatic cell system parameters and operational data
fulltext_extractions.metric: System efficiency, downtime reduction, resource utilization optimization
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Traditional proprietary automation tools and manual industrial processes
fulltext_extractions.result: Cost-effective alternatives using graphics engines reduce economic costs while providing realistic industrial environment simulation with multiple enabling technologies

fulltext_extractions.problem: Understanding why Lepidoptera (butterflies and moths) display very high radioresistance compared to mammals and other insect orders, with a focus on the role of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) in cellular radiation sensitivity.
fulltext_extractions.method: In silico comparative analysis of NOS structural features, including sequence homology, predicted tertiary structure, post-translational phosphorylation sites (using Net Phos 2.0), and intracellular localization (using WoLFPSORT) across Lepidopteran, Dipteran, and mammalian species.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Lepidopteran NOS has significantly higher phosphorylation scores (0.885) than mammalian NOS (0.694) and predominantly cytoplasmic localization, which reduces NOS activation and prevents oxidative damage amplification in the nucleus and mitochondria, contributing to radioresistance.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: Lepidopteran, Dipteran (Drosophila), and mammalian NOS sequences; computed predictions from online tools
fulltext_extractions.metric: Phosphorylation score (Net Phos 2.0), subcellular localization score (WoLFPSORT)
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Mammalian nNOS (neuronal), Dipteran NOS
fulltext_extractions.result: Lepidopteran NOS phosphorylation score 0.885±0.02 vs mammalian 0.694±0.094; Lepidopteran cytoplasmic localization score 23 vs mammalian 10

fulltext_extractions.problem: Virtual reality (VR) systems for studying spatial navigation in head-fixed rodents have not revealed 2D firing patterns characteristic of real open arenas. Uncertain whether neural processes in VR match real-world spatial navigation.
fulltext_extractions.method: Head-restrained mouse VR system with chronically implanted head-plate constraining movements to horizontal rotations. Compatible with multi-photon imaging. Compared place cell, grid cell, and head-direction cell firing patterns between VR and real arenas.
fulltext_extractions.finding: Place and grid cells had broader spatial tuning in VR than real arenas, but grid cell firing maintained 2D patterns. Place cells were more directional in real arenas. Theta frequency increased less with running speed in VR. Firing rates and theta phase precession were similar between VR and real environments.
fulltext_extractions.dataset: 11 trained mice; recordings from hippocampal place cells and grid cells
fulltext_extractions.metric: Spatial tuning width; theta frequency; firing rate; theta phase precession; directional modulation
fulltext_extractions.baseline: Real open arena behavior and firing patterns
fulltext_extractions.result: VR successfully shows 2D spatial cell firing; differences attributed to missing local cues and vestibular signals in VR compared to real navigation
